The effectiveness of the US government's propaganda tactics in convincing the American public to support the war is a matter of debate. While the government's propaganda efforts did help to maintain public support for the war effort in the early years, this support began to erode as the war dragged on and the human and financial costs continued to mount.

The growing opposition to the war among the American people was fueled by a variety of factors, including the increasing number of casualties, the lack of progress in the war effort, the draft and the unfair treatment of poor and minority Americans, and the increasing anti-war sentiment expressed by the counterculture movement.

Ultimately, the propaganda efforts of the US government were not enough to overcome the growing opposition to the war and the American people's desire to end the conflict. The Vietnam War eventually became one of the most divisive and controversial wars in American history, and its legacy continues to be debated and studied to this day.
